title: ‘Don’t Kill Me’: Others Tell of Abuse by Officer Who Knelt on George Floyd
description: New firsthand accounts accuse Derek Chauvin, the police officer who pressed his knee into George Floyd’s neck in Minneapolis, of using similar tactics on detainees over the years.
Zoya Code says the Minneapolis police officer who knelt on George Floyd until he complained he could not breathe treated her roughly as well.
creator: Jamiles Lartey and Abbie VanSickle

title: Biden Inherits Family Separation Crisis From Trump
description: President Biden will form a task force to reunite migrant families separated at the border under a Trump-era policy. Families want restitution, mental health services and green cards as compensation.
Children lined up to enter a tent at the Homestead Temporary Shelter for Unaccompanied Children in Homestead, Fla.
creator: Miriam Jordan

title: Apple Reports Second Quarter Results
description: Apple today announced financial results for its fiscal 2016 second quarter ended March 26.
The company posted quarterly revenue of $50.6 billion and quarterly net income of $10.5 billion, or $1.90 per diluted share.
These results compare to revenue of $58 billion and net income of $13.6 billion, or $2.33 per diluted share, in the year-ago quarter.
Gross margin was 39.4 percent compared to 40.8 percent in the year-ago quarter. International sales accounted for 67 percent of the quarter’s revenue.

'Our team executed extremely well in the face of strong macroeconomic headwinds,' said Tim Cook, Apple’s CEO. 'We are very happy with the continued strong growth in revenue from Services, thanks to the incredible strength of the Apple ecosystem and our growing base of over 1 billion active devices.'
creator: Kristin Huguet Quayle

title: Final Cut Pro X helps small company delight world’s biggest clients
description: When Trim Editing started creating music videos over a decade ago, just paying the rent was a huge accomplishment. Now, the small East London company is crafting award-winning visuals for big brands — like Audi, Nike, Adidas, and Guinness — propelled by the power of Final Cut Pro X. The video editing software’s comprehensive features allow Trim Editing to organize film and audio clips, pull together compelling projects, and make changes on the fly. “When I’m playing back an edit for a director, they’ll say, ‘Okay, let’s go and make those changes I talked about.’ I’ll say, ‘Oh, no, they’re already done,’ and we’ll jump back and watch it again. People can’t believe that I’ve magically done the change before we even finish playback,” says editor Thomas Grove Carter. '
creator: Kristin Huguet Quayle
category: Final Cut Pro X helps small company delight world’s biggest clients6

title: Prominent Lebanese Hezbollah critic found killed in his car
creator: Kristin Huguet Quayle
category: Prominent Lebanese Hezbollah critic found killed in his car

title: The ‘Dr. Fauci’ of the Texas Border Is Counting the Dead
description: Laredo, Texas, is enduring the country’s worst outbreak at the end of the pandemic’s deadliest month. A crusading cardiologist, leading the fight, is begging the state to close down his city.
“Five to seven death certificates, that’s how many I’m signing every single day,” said Dr. Ricardo Cigarroa, a cardiologist.
creator: Simon Romero

title: After Capitol Riot, Elected Officials Under Pressure Back Home
description: At least 19 state and local elected officeholders from across the country attended the Jan. 6 rally and, in some cases, stormed the Capitol.
Former President Donald J. Trump spoke at a rally in front of the White House on Jan. 6.
creator: Hailey Fuchs

title: Politics latest news: Closing borders completely deemed 'probably ineffective' by Sage, claims minister
description: Michelle Donelan, the Universities Minister, has said the committee actually advised that a full border closure would be 'ineffective', and recommended quarantine and testing for arrivals instead.
Leaked advice from the Government’s Sage committee that was published in The Times, suggests ministers were warned of the dangers of the new South African variant at least two weeks ago.
creator: Carl D. Pearson

title: U.S. Cities Are Vastly Undercounting Emissions, Researchers Find
description: Inconsistent and flawed data is undercutting efforts to reduce greenhouse gas emissions from American cities, according to a new study.
San Francisco at dusk. Nearly three-quarters of the carbon dioxide generated from fossil fuels in the United States comes from cities.
creator: John Schwartz

title: Is Seeing That Renoir Essential? In the Pandemic, Cities Differ
description: Arizona has allowed its museums to remain open despite a deadly outbreak, while in cities and states with far fewer cases, the doors have been closed.
The Metropolitan Museum of Art in New York reopened, with limited capacity, in late August. Unlike museums in other parts of the country, the Met has not been forced to close again.
creator: Julia Jacobs

title: Kehinde Wiley’s Black Rock Resident Artists Are Named
description: Members of the global group share the painter’s passion for using art to explore social change.
Kehinde Wiley at the Black Rock artist residence he founded in Dakar, Senegal, in 2019. It is welcoming its second group of artists, filmmakers and writers from around the world.
creator: Dionne Searcey

title: Muskogee Shooting: 5 Children, One Man Shot and Killed in Oklahoma
description: The police in Muskogee, Okla., said they caught the person believed to be the gunman, but did not identify the man or the victims.
creator: Maria Cramer

title: Trump Had Greatest Loss of Support in 2020 with White Male Voters
description: Supporters of President Trump during a campaign rally at the Wilkes-Barre Scranton International Airport in Avoca, Pa., in November.
creator: Maggie Haberman

title: Florida FBI Shooting: 2 Agents Killed While Serving Warrant in Sunrise
description: Three other agents were injured. The shooting occurred as agents were serving a warrant in the city of Sunrise, west of Fort Lauderdale, the authorities said.
The police responded to an apartment complex in Sunrise, Fla., on Tuesday after a shooting that occurred as F.B.I. agents were serving a warrant, the authorities said.
creator: Johnny Diaz and Adam Goldman

title: Theresa May confused 'stubbornness with heroism' during Brexit process, says Philip Hammond
description: In a damning interview about his former boss, Lord Hammond said Mrs May had a 'romantic notion of charging into the valley
even though you know you’re going down to certain defeat' as she tried to pass her Brexit agreement amid hostility from her own party.
creator: Tony Diver

title: Winter Snow Storm Was Among Biggest in NYC History
description: More than 17 inches of snow fell in Central Park, making it New York City’s biggest snowstorm in five years.
creator: Daniel E. Slotnik

title: What Californians Can Learn From Texas Republicans
description: Tuesday: California is in a time of political transition. It’s sort of like what Texas went through four years ago.
Representative Kevin McCarthy has shown continuing loyalty to former President Donald Trump, even as he has faced intense criticism for doing so.
creator: Jill Cowan and Manny Fernandez

title: Myanmar, Russia pose early tests for Biden's foreign policy
description: A military coup in Myanmar and a mass crackdown on dissidents in Russia are presenting early tests for the Biden administration as it tries to reestablish American
primacy as a worldwide pro-democracy leader. Having taken office with a pledge to restore ironclad U.S. support for human rights, freedom of speech and political openness,
President Joe Biden is being confronted with two serious challenges in two disparate parts of the world that had either been neglected or the subject of inconsistent messaging during the Trump era.
creator: Matthew Lee

title: Florida man charged with trying to join ISIS
description: A former Florida resident has been returned to the United States after traveling to Turkey and attempting to join the Islamic State group.
The U.S. Attorney's Office in Gainesville announced Monday that Mohamed Fathy Suliman, 33, a U.S. citizen, has been charged with attempting to provide
material support for a designated foreign terrorist organization. If convicted, he faces up to 20 years in prison.
creator: Matthew Lee

title: Even in Poorer Neighborhoods, the Wealthy Are Lining Up for Vaccines
description: Officials acknowledge that the coveted shots are disproportionately going to white people and that planners’ efforts to course-correct are having limited effect.

description.__text: Rose Woodside, 93, left, and her daughter, Adora Lee, 70, talking to a nurse at a pre-vaccine screening in Washington, D.C. They obtained appointments after the city began giving priority to people in neighborhoods hit hardest by the virus.

credit.__text: Kenny Holston for The New York Times

title: The Case of the Serial Sperm Donor
description: One man, hundreds of children and a burning question: Why?

title: Alzheimer’s Prediction May Be Found in Writing Tests
description: IBM researchers trained artificial intelligence to pick up hints of changes in language ahead of the onset of neurological diseases.

description.__text: An M.R.I. scan of a patient over the age of 60 with Alzheimer’s disease.

title: Have You Had Covid-19? Study Says You May Need Only One Vaccine Dose
description: People who have already been sick with Covid-19 should still be vaccinated, experts say, but they may experience intense side effects even after one dose.

description.__text: People who received Moderna’s Covid-19 vaccine sat in a waiting area at a vaccination site in San Diego, Calif.

credit.__text: Ariana Drehsler for The New York Times

title: Which Covid Vaccine Should You Get? Experts Cite the Effect Against Severe Disease
description: Infectious disease doctors say getting a shot of the J&J vaccine, which has a lower efficacy against the virus than other vaccines, would still be well worthwhile.

description.__text: Covid vaccinations in Santa Barbara County, Calif., this week.

credit.__text: Daniel Dreifuss for The New York Times

title: How the Search for Covid-19 Treatments Faltered While Vaccines Sped Ahead
description: Vaccine development exceeded everyone’s expectations. But the next few months will still bring many sick people — and doctors have woefully few drugs with which to treat them.

description.__text: A makeshift I.C.U. at a hospital in Torrance, Calif, earlier this month.

title: Johnson & Johnson’s Vaccine Offers Strong Protection but Fuels Concern About Variants
description: The vaccine’s efficacy rate dropped from 72 percent in the United States to just 57 percent in South Africa, where a highly contagious variant is driving most cases.

description.__text: A dose of Johnson & Johnson’s vaccine candidate was prepared at the Rocky Mountain Regional VA Medical Center in Aurora, Colo., last month.

creator.__text: Carl Zimmer, Noah Weiland and Sharon LaFraniere

title: Novavax’s Vaccine Works Well — Except on Variant First Found in South Africa
description: An early analysis in Britain found that the vaccine had an efficacy rate of nearly 90 percent. But in a small South Africa trial, the efficacy rate dropped to just under 50 percent.

description.__text: A patient participating in Novavax’s late-stage vaccine trial at Howard University in Washington this month.

creator.__text: Katie Thomas, Carl Zimmer and Sharon LaFraniere

credit.__text: Kenny Holston for The New York Times

title: Health Care Unions Find a Voice as the Pandemic Rages
description: Faced with the urgent need to protect nurses and other frontline workers, labor organizations are pushing hospitals to do more.

description.__text: Kayla Wilson, a registered nurse, used her lunch break to join nurses demonstrating  last month against unsafe staffing practices at Good Samaritan Hospital in San Jose, Calif.

creator.__text: Ian Prasad Philbrick and Reed Abelson

credit.__text: Sarahbeth Maney for The New York Times

title: The Hidden Epidemic on Travel’s Front Line
description: More than 6,000 employees of the Transportation Security Administration have contracted the coronavirus. Workers say lax safety measures have contributed to the spread.

description.__text: LaShanda Palmer, a Transportation Security Administration officer at  Philadelphia International Airport. Though she caught the virus in March, she worries that her work at the airport may cause her to bring home the virus to her family members.

credit.__text: Steve Legato for The New York Times

title: I’m a Disabled Parent. It Took a Pandemic to Let Me Join the P.T.A.
description: My chronic illness made it hard to volunteer at my kids’ school. Now I can serve on the executive board of the P.T.A. without leaving my bed.

title: The Virus Variant Spreading in Britain May Make Vaccines Less Effective, Study Shows

description.__text: Researchers at Aalborg University in Denmark analyzing coronavirus samples for the variant B.1.1.7 last month.

title: ¿Qué vacuna debo ponerme?
description: Los especialistas en enfermedades infecciosas afirman que vacunarse con la vacuna de Johnson & Johnson, cuya eficacia contra el virus es menor que la de otras vacunas, seguiría mereciendo la pena.

description.__text: Vacunación contra la covid en el condado de Santa Bárbara, California, la semana pasada

credit.__text: Daniel Dreifuss para The New York Times

title: Tony Bennett Reveals He Has Alzheimer’s Disease
description: “He’s not the old Tony anymore,” his wife, Susan, said. “But when he sings, he’s the old Tony.”

description.__text: The singer Tony Bennett has announced that he has Alzheimer’s disease, writing on Twitter: “Life is a gift — even with Alzheimer’s.”

title: How Climate Change May Affect Your Health
description: No matter where you live or how high your socioeconomic status, climate change can endanger your health, both physical and mental, now and in the future.

category.__text: Centers for Disease Control and Prevention

title: Fact Check: Hank Aaron's Death Was Not Related to Covid-19 Vaccine
description: Anti-vaccine activists, including Robert F. Kennedy Jr., are seizing on the baseball legend’s death to suggest — without evidence — that there might be a link to his Covid vaccination.

description.__text: Hank Aaron preparing to receive his Covid-19 vaccination on Jan. 5 at the Morehouse School of Medicine in Atlanta.

title: Andrew Brooks, Who Developed a Coronavirus Spit Test, Dies at 51
description: His breakthrough helped millions get their results quickly in the early days of the pandemic, when tests were scarce and lines were long.

description.__text: Andrew Brooks in April 2020 at his lab at Rutgers. He made worldwide news after the Covid-19 saliva test he developed received emergency approval from the Food and Drug Administration.

category.__text: Rutgers, The State University of New Jersey

title: Erasure Poetry At Home
description: Creating an erasure poem means finding your voice lurking in another’s words. It can be a way to start writing when words fail.

title: Divorce During the Pandemic
description: Our routines may have stalled during Covid, but the desire to divorce certainly hasn’t. Here, some of the pandemic-age challenges to consider.

title: Make Bath Bombs At Home
description: Your first batch of scent, salt and fizz may not be beautiful, but you’ll know exactly what you’re introducing to your tub.

title: How to Have A Safe Super Bowl Sunday
description: Go team! Even if your watch party is small or on Zoom, there are games and other activities to get even the most casual fan involved and engaged.

title: How to Downscale Your Super Bowl Spread
description: You probably won’t be watching with a crowd, but you can still have wings, dip and a sub-style sandwich to eat during the game.

credit.__text: Yossy Arefi for The New York Times

title: Things To Do At Home
description: This week, learn about metamorphosing insects, dance your way through the Cleveland Museum of Art or watch a documentary.

title: Evidence Builds That Pregnant Women Pass Covid Antibodies to Newborns
description: A new study suggests that protective antibodies can be transferred through the placenta, and the baby may receive more of them if a mother is infected with Covid earlier in her pregnancy.

description.__text: A woman  in McAllen, Tex., who tested positive for Covid-19 while she was pregnant. Studies suggest that pregnant women infected with the coronavirus can pass antibodies to their babies.

title: ‘It’s Numbing’: Nine Retired Nuns in Michigan Die of Covid-19
description: The deaths add to what is becoming a familiar trend in the spread of the virus as it devastates religious congregate communities by infecting retired, aging populations of nuns and sisters.

description.__text: Nine Roman Catholic nuns died in January of Covid-19 at the retirement home of the Adrian Dominican Sisters in Adrian, Mich.

creator.__text: Christine Hauser and Concepción de León

credit.__text: Mike Dickie/The Daily Telegram, via Associated Press

title: Pregnant Women May Receive Covid Vaccines Safely, W.H.O. Says
description: The change aligns the organization with the guidance from the U.S. Centers for Disease Control and Prevention.

description.__text: A pregnant woman being vaccinated in Tel Aviv.

category.__text: Centers for Disease Control and Prevention

title: Health care unions amplify the voices of frontline workers overwhelmed by pandemic conditions.

description.__text: Registered nurses demonstrated against unsafe staffing practices at Good Samaritan Hospital in San Jose, Calif., in December.

creator.__text: Ian Prasad Philbrick and Reed Abelson

credit.__text: Sarahbeth Maney for The New York Times

title: A Pandemic Is Hard Enough. For Some, Being Single Has Made It Harder.
description: “One day I realized it had been three months since I had touched a human being,” one man said.

description.__text: A lone swimmer during a lockdown in Thailand in January.

title: What It’s Like to Give the Covid Vaccine
description: A doctor couple is working to get disadvantaged communities “their fair shot at getting the shot.”

title: Helping a Teen Who Is Angry About House Rules on Covid
description: Our grandson’s friends don’t socialize safely, so we don’t want him to see them. How do we keep his anger about it from causing chaos in our home?

title: Pregnant Women Get Conflicting Advice on Covid-19 Vaccines
description: The W.H.O. and the C.D.C. provide differing views, and experts partly blame a lack of data because expectant mothers have been excluded from clinical trials.

description.__text: A pregnant woman being vaccinated in Tel Aviv. The C.D.C. and the W.H.O. differ in their guidance for expectant mothers.

creator.__text: Apoorva Mandavilli and Roni Caryn Rabin

category.__text: Centers for Disease Control and Prevention

title: Biden Re-Opens Obamacare Enrollment Period in 36 States
description: Evidence from states that also reopened enrollment suggests it could pull more young, healthy Americans into insurance coverage.

description.__text: President Biden discussing health care and the Affordable Care Act last month. Today he signed an executive order for a new 90-day enrollment period on Healthcare.gov.

category.__text: Patient Protection and Affordable Care Act (2010)

title: How the Coronavirus Turns the Body Against Itself
description: Some patients struggling with Covid-19 develop antibodies against their own tissues, scientists have found.

description.__text: A Covid-19 patient at Sharp Grossmont Hospital in La Mesa, Calif., this month. Some patients produce antibodies similar to those produced in more familiar diseases, like lupus.

title: From Michael Lewis, a ‘Superhero Story’ About the Pandemic
description: The author of “The Big Short” and “Moneyball” takes on a frightening subject in his new book “The Premonition”: how to prevent a viral outbreak even worse than Covid-19.

description.__text: “It’s a superhero story where the superheroes seem to lose the war,” Michael Lewis said of his next book, “The Premonition,” “but all they’ve lost is a battle.”

credit.__text: Peter Prato for The New York Times

title: What Can Covid-19 Teach Us About the Mysteries of Smell?
description: The virus’s strangest symptom has opened new doors to understanding our most neglected sense.

credit.__text: Stephanie Gonot for The New York Times

title: Thailand Legalizes Abortion in 1st Trimester but Keeps Other Restrictions
description: Women who end a pregnancy after 12 weeks could still face prison or fines. Abortion rights advocates say more change is needed.

description.__text: Supporting abortion rights at a march in Bangkok in November.

category.__text: Human Rights and Human Rights Violations

title: A New Option for Morning-After Contraception?
description: An hormonal IUD may work as well as morning-after pills for preventing pregnancy, a new study suggests.

title: A ‘Baby’ Aspirin a Day May Help Prevent a Second Pregnancy Loss
description: Women who have had a pregnancy loss and are trying to get pregnant again may benefit from a daily low-dose aspirin.

title: As More Deaf People Are Seen on TV, Others Want to Be Heard
description: Some deaf people identify with shows like “Deaf U.” For others, a deaf contestant on “The Bachelor” who doesn’t use sign language is a welcome change.

description.__text: From left, Cheyenna Clearbrook, Daequan Taylor and Rodney Burford in “Deaf U,” a Netflix reality series that followed students at Gallaudet University.

title: With All Eyes on Covid-19, Drug-Resistant Infections Crept In
description: The spread of other dangerous germs is surging — a result, in part, of the chaotic response to the pandemic.

description.__text: A hospital worker disinfecting a room where a Covid patient had died. Focus on the coronavirus has helped a different set of germs spread.

category.__text: Centers for Disease Control and Prevention

title: The Best Time of Day to Exercise
description: Men at risk for diabetes had greater blood sugar control and lost more belly fat when they exercised in the afternoon than in the morning.

title: Christina Crosby, 67, Dies; Feminist Scholar Wrote of Becoming Disabled
description: After a bicycle accident left her paralyzed, she wrote a memoir, “A Body, Undone,” which refused to draw tidy lessons about overcoming hardship.

title: Aetna to Expand Coverage for Gender-Affirming Surgeries
description: One of the nation’s largest health insurers is agreeing to pay for breast augmentation for some trans women.

description.__text: Two years ago, Cora Brna, a health care worker in Pittsburgh, was devastated to learn that her insurance would not cover the breast augmentation she had planned to have along with a genital reassignment surgery.

credit.__text: Sarah Huny Young for The New York Times

title: Biden's Executive Orders: President to Sign 3 Rolling Back Trump's Immigration Agenda
description: One executive order aims to reunite migrant families separated at the southern border. The others authorize a wholesale review of the former president’s immigration policies.

Undocumented families at a bus station in McAllen, Texas. The three executive orders underscore the difficulty that the new president faces in unraveling scores of individual policies and regulations.
creator: Michael D. Shear
credit: Ilana Panich-Linsman for The New York Times

title: Investigation Has Not Found Evidence to Charge Officer in Ashli Babbitt’s Death
description: The investigation into the fatal shooting of Ashli Babbitt was not complete, officials cautioned, and no recommendation had been made to prosecutors yet.
A memorial outside the Capitol last month to Ashli Babbitt, a Trump supporter who was shot by the police when she was part of the mob that stormed the building.
creator: Katie Benner

title: North Carolina Discontinues License Plates With Confederate Flag
description: The Division of Motor Vehicles said it had received complaints about the specialty plate, which had been issued to members of the Sons of Confederate Veterans.
creator: Neil Vigdor

title: Mitch McConnell Says Marjorie Taylor Green’s ‘Loony Lies’ Are a ‘Cancer’ on GOP
description: Senator Mitch McConnell issued a scathing rebuke on Monday saying that the “loony lies and conspiracy theories” embraced by Ms. Greene amounted to a “cancer” on the Republican Party.
Senate Minority Leader Mitch McConnell of Kentucky had strong words about Representative Marjorie Taylor Greene, Republican of Georgia.
creator: Catie Edmondson
credit: Oliver Contreras for The New York Times

title: Trump's Lawyers Are Unlikely to Focus on Election Fraud Claims
description: While Mr. Trump has argued for it, his lawyers will instead echo the argument of many Republicans that the impeachment trial of a former president is unconstitutional.
Bruce L. Castor Jr., a former district attorney in Pennsylvania, joined former President Donald J. Trump’s legal team this weekend.
creator: Maggie Haberman and Nicholas Fandos

title: Republicans Pitch Biden on Smaller Aid Plan as Democrats Prepare to Act Alone
description: The president met at the White House with Republican senators seeking a much smaller stimulus plan, but congressional Democrats pressed forward to force through his $1.9 trillion measure, if necessary.
President Biden and Vice President Kamala Harris met with Republican senators on Monday about a stimulus plan.
creator: Luke Broadwater and Jim Tankersley
category: Coronavirus Aid, Relief, and Economic Security Act (2020)

title: Tim Ryan Is Said to Plan Senate Bid
description: Mr. Ryan, who mounted a long-shot campaign for president in 2019, plans to compete for the state’s open Senate seat. His campaign will test Democrats’ strength in a state tilting to the right.
Representative Tim Ryan of Ohio has argued that Democrats will build enduring majorities only if they reclaim support from a multiracial, working-class coalition of voters.
creator: Jonathan Martin
credit: Rachel Mummey for The New York Times

title: Coronavirus Briefing: What Happened Today
description: A hiccup in one country can become a tragedy for everyone.
creator: Jonathan Wolfe

title: How Trump Is Pocketing Donors' Cash for the Future
description: With breathless, often misleading appeals, the former president promised small donors that he was using the money to fight the election results, but in fact stored much of it for future use.

Protesters outside the Supreme Court in December. Many Republican grass-roots donors were drawn in by former President Donald J. Trump’s false promises and “stop the steal” message after the November election.
creator: Shane Goldmacher and Rachel Shorey
credit: Anna Moneymaker for The New York Times

title: Watchdogs Appointed by Trump Pose Dilemma for Biden
description: Removing inspectors general installed by the former president under a political cloud could have the consequence of further eroding good-government norms.
Only one Democrat in the Senate voted to confirm Brian D. Miller, who had been a White House lawyer for President Donald J. Trump, as an inspector general hunting for abuses in pandemic spending.
creator: Charlie Savage
category: Coronavirus Aid, Relief, and Economic Security Act (2020)

title: Jack Palladino, 76, Hard-Charging Private Investigator, Dies After ‘Brutal Attack’
description: Mr. Palladino, a private investigator who had worked for Bill Clinton and other famous clients, died four days after he sustained a severe head injury in an attempted robbery, the authorities said.
Jack Palladino rose to national prominence in the 1990s, when he was hired by Bill Clinton, then a presidential candidate, after allegations of an extramarital affair made by Gennifer Flowers.
creator: Michael Levenson and Alan Yuhas
credit: Eric Luse/San Francisco Chronicle, via Associated Press

title: How Rich Hospitals Profit From Patients in Car Crashes
description: Hospitals use century-old lien laws to bypass insurers and charge patients, especially poorer ones, the full amount.
Located north of Fort Wayne, Ind., Parkview Regional Medical Center placed a $12,856 lien on Monica Smith’s automobile accident settlement.
creator: Sarah Kliff and Jessica Silver-Greenberg
credit: Amy Powell for The New York Times

title: Trump Official’s Last-Day Deal With ICE Union Ties Biden’s Hands
description: A whistle-blower accused Kenneth T. Cuccinelli II of an abuse of power in making sweeping concessions to pro-Trump Immigration and Customs Enforcement agents.

Kenneth T. Cuccinelli, a homeland security official in the Trump administration, is accused of acting without legal authority to sabotage President Biden’s ability to manage Immigration and Customs Enforcement.
creator: Zolan Kanno-Youngs and Charlie Savage

title: U.S. Aircraft Carrier Returning Home After Long Sea Tour Watching Iran
description: The Pentagon had extended the deployment of the Nimitz in the Middle East after Iranian threats against President Donald J. Trump and U.S. troops in the region.
Navy sailors aboard the aircraft carrier Nimitz last year. The ship was ordered on Sunday to return to its home port of Bremerton, Wash.
creator: Eric Schmitt
category: United States Defense and Military Forces

title: What Is GameStop, the Company, Really Worth? Does It Matter?
description: The frenzy for the troubled retailer’s stock has been a head-scratcher for the analysts who try to determine a company’s value.
The huge disconnect between GameStop’s stock price and how the company is actually performing has created one of the more bizarre moments in Wall Street history.
creator: Peter Eavis
credit: Philip Cheung for The New York Times

title: Jamie Tarses, Executive in a Hollywood Rise-and-Fall Story, Dies at 56
description: She broke barriers as a woman in the TV industry and turned out hit after hit, only to see it all fizzle under a very public spotlight.
creator: Brooks Barnes

title: The warming Arctic plays a role in storms like the one hitting the Northeast.
description: People walking in the Bronx during the storm on Monday.
creator: John Schwartz
credit: Gabriela Bhaskar for The New York Times

title: Dustin Diamond, Actor on ‘Saved by the Bell,’ Dies at 44
description: Mr. Diamond played Screech on the NBC high school sitcom, but struggled to find work and reconcile with cast members in the decades after the show ended.
Dustin Diamond as Samuel “Screech” Powers on “Saved by the Bell,” a Saturday morning staple on NBC from 1989 to 1992.
creator: Johnny Diaz
credit: Paul Drinkwater/NBCU Photo Bank, via Getty Images

title: Have You Had Covid-19? Study Says You May Need Only One Vaccine Dose
description: People who have already been sick with Covid-19 should still be vaccinated, experts say, but they may experience intense side effects even after one dose.
People who received Moderna’s Covid-19 vaccine sat in a waiting area at a vaccination site in San Diego, Calif.
creator: Cassandra Willyard
credit: Ariana Drehsler for The New York Times

title: Tony Bennett Reveals He Has Alzheimer’s Disease
description: “He’s not the old Tony anymore,” his wife, Susan, said. “But when he sings, he’s the old Tony.”
The singer Tony Bennett has announced that he has Alzheimer’s disease, writing on Twitter: “Life is a gift — even with Alzheimer’s.”
creator: Sarah Bahr

title: Evan Rachel Wood Accuses Marilyn Manson of Abuse
description: “He started grooming me when I was a teenager and horrifically abused me for years,” Ms. Wood, said on Instagram. Hours later Mr. Manson’s label dropped him.
The rock musician Marilyn Manson last year. Mr. Manson and the actress Evan Rachel Wood publicly became a couple in 2007, when she was 19 and he was 38.
creator: Jenny Gross and Melena Ryzik
credit: Randy Shropshire/Getty Images for The Art of Elysium
